You should know that you have choices! Virginia is one of 27 states with an "Any Willing Provider" law, meaning health insurance companies are required to allow providers (like pharmacies) to become "in network" if certain conditions are met.

Several constituents who joined our #VA07 town hall mentioned that their insurance requires them to use a specific pharmacy. That limitation has become burdensome for many, as some pharmacies adapt better than others to the challenges of COVID-19 and unreliable mail delivery.

Today, @EPA is holding a public hearing on its NAAQS proposal for ozone pollution. We call on @EPA to set stronger, more protective standards.

Amid an already deadly pandemic, @EPA proposed a standard that we know puts the elderly and those living with diseases like asthma ‚Äì some of the very same people at higher risk of adverse #COVID19 outcomes ‚Äì at higher risk.

Despite staff recommendations and the science clearly dictating a stronger standard to protect public health, @EPA decided against setting stronger standards to protect people from ozone pollution. https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-environment/2020/07/13/epa-air-pollution/

During the review process for its ozone pollution proposal, the Trump @EPA disbanded the scientific experts tasked with helping the agency review the latest ozone health studies. 
https://www.sciencemag.org/news/2018/10/trump-s-epa-scraps-air-pollution-science-review-panels

Protective ozone standards are especially important during an outbreak of a deadly respiratory pandemic like the one we‚Äôre experiencing now ‚Äì one that we know is particularly dangerous for individuals with all types of lung diseases.

The American people depend on the EPA to implement ozone health standards to protect our nation‚Äôs most vulnerable people from suffocating smog pollution, including the millions of children that live with asthma.

Every five years EPA is required to review the best available science to determine if the NAAQS for ozone pollution is still protective of public health.

If the science shows a more protective NAAQS is needed, EPA is required to make changes to the NAAQS.
The Clean Air Act requires EPA to set national ambient air quality standards (NAAQS) for ozone pollution.

Ozone pollution is harmful and linked to serious health problems, like asthma, strokes, heart attacks and even early deaths. These pollutants are found disproportionately in communities of color, low income communities, and indigenous communities. 
https://www.vox.com/2020/4/11/21217040/coronavirus-in-us-air-pollution-asthma-black-americans
When pollution emitted from cars, power plants, refineries, chemical plants and other sources reacts with heat and sunlight, it creates ground-level ozone pollution.
